tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: The question requires applying the concept of pressure coefficient and its relation to airfoil geometry. It involves understanding how scaling affects pressure distribution, integrating concepts of aerodynamics and fluid mechanics. The difficulty is medium as it requires understanding of multiple concepts.

answer_validation.reasoning: Pressure coefficient \(C_p\) is a nondimensional parameter defined using local and freestream pressures and dynamic pressure. For geometrically similar airfoils of the same family, operating at the same angle of attack and same flow conditions (same Mach and Reynolds numbers), the pressure distribution in nondimensional form is identical. Therefore the minimum pressure coefficient \(C_{p,\min}\) is the same for both airfoils, independent of absolute size. Hence the ratio \(C_{p,\min,\,\text{large}} / C_{p,\min,\,\text{small}} = 1.0\).

step_by_step: Step 1: Recall the definition of pressure coefficient: \(C_p = \dfrac{p - p_\infty}{\tfrac{1}{2} \rho_\infty V_\infty^2}\). It is nondimensional and compares local pressure to freestream dynamic pressure.

Step 2: For geometrically similar airfoils of the same family at the same angle of attack, and under dynamically similar flow (same Mach and Reynolds numbers), the nondimensional pressure distribution \(C_p(x/c)\) is identical.

Step 3: The minimum pressure coefficient \(C_{p,\min}\) is just the minimum value of this nondimensional distribution. Since the distributions are identical in nondimensional coordinates, their minima are equal.
Step 4: Changing the absolute size (doubling all dimensions) does not change \(C_p\) values; it only scales dimensional quantities like forces, but not nondimensional coefficients.
Step 5: Therefore, the minimum pressure coefficient for the larger airfoil equals that of the smaller airfoil, and the ratio is 1.0.

topic.name: Similarity and Nondimensional Coefficients in External Flows
topic.syllabus_ref: Section 2 Aerodynamics -> Incompressible and compressible flow over airfoils and wings; similarity parameters, aerodynamic coefficients

essential: Definition and physical meaning of pressure coefficient
Concept of geometric similarity of airfoils
Dynamic similarity: role of Mach and Reynolds numbers
Difference between dimensional forces and nondimensional coefficients
helpful: Understanding of lift coefficient and its independence from scale under similarity
Basic knowledge of airfoil pressure distribution plots
Awareness of airfoil families (same shape, different scale)

Main Concept: requires: Definition of pressure coefficient as a nondimensional parameter
requires: Concept of geometric and dynamic similarity in aerodynamics
enables: Ability to predict how aerodynamic coefficients change (or not) with scale
enables: Advanced wind-tunnel testing and model-to-full-scale extrapolation

difficulty_factors: Requires recognizing that Cp is nondimensional and scale-independent under similarity
Students may confuse scaling of forces (which change with size) with coefficients (which do not)

textbook_references.author: John D. Anderson
textbook_references.chapter_title: Basic Aerodynamics: Airfoils, Wings, and Other Aerodynamic Shapes
textbook_references.section: 3.3 Aerodynamic Force Coefficients and Similarity Parameters
textbook_references.text_snippet: The lift and drag coefficients and the pressure coefficient are nondimensional parameters that, for geometrically similar bodies in dynamically similar flows, are independent of the absolute size of the body.

textbook_references.author: J. D. Anderson
textbook_references.text_snippet: Profile drag (c_d) and lift slope are defined as nondimensional quantities; for a given airfoil family and flow similarity, these coefficients are independent of scale.

textbook_references.author: E. Rathakrishnan
textbook_references.text_snippet: Similarity rules allow the use of data from one airfoil to predict the performance of a family of related airfoils. The nondimensional coefficients such as C_p, C_L, and C_M are used to relate these flows.

video_references.professor: J. D. Anderson (lecture series references, various instructors)
video_references.topic_covered: Similarity parameters, Reynolds and Mach number, and scale effects on aerodynamic coefficients

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Recall definition of Cp \u2192 Recall similarity principle \u2192 Apply to two similar airfoils \u2192 Note scale independence of Cp \u2192 Compute ratio
key_insights: Pressure coefficient is nondimensional and, under geometric and dynamic similarity, does not depend on absolute size.
Being of the same family and at same angle of attack implies identical nondimensional pressure distributions.

formulas_principles.name: Pressure coefficient definition
formulas_principles.conditions: Valid for both incompressible and compressible flows when using appropriate freestream properties
formulas_principles.relevance: Core definition showing Cp is nondimensional and independent of body size under similarity

formulas_principles.name: Section lift coefficient definition
formulas_principles.conditions: Two-dimensional airfoil, c is chord length
formulas_principles.relevance: Illustrates that lift coefficient, like Cp, is nondimensional and scale-independent under similarity

formulas_principles.name: Functional dependence of pressure coefficient
formulas_principles.conditions: External flow over airfoil; f is same for geometrically similar airfoils at same Mach, Reynolds, and angle of attack
formulas_principles.relevance: Expresses that Cp distribution depends on nondimensional coordinates and similarity parameters, not absolute scale

industry_examples: Wind-tunnel testing of scale models: Engineers test a small-scale wing or airfoil in a wind tunnel and use the measured Cp distribution to predict full-scale aircraft performance, relying on the fact that Cp is scale-independent under similarity.
Airfoil database usage: NACA and modern airfoil databases provide Cp, Cl, and Cd data that can be applied to wings of many different sizes as long as geometric and dynamic similarity are maintained.
specific_systems: Commercial transport aircraft wings (e.g., Airbus A320, Boeing 737) whose airfoil sections are designed and validated using smaller wind-tunnel models.
Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) that may use the same airfoil family as larger aircraft but at different scales.
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Understanding that nondimensional coefficients like Cp do not change with scale under similarity allows engineers to use small, cheaper models to accurately predict full-scale performance, saving cost and development time.

common_mistakes.mistake: Assuming that doubling the size of the airfoil doubles the minimum pressure coefficient (choosing ratio 2.0).
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They confuse dimensional quantities (like force or pressure difference) with nondimensional coefficients and think everything scales linearly with size.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always check whether the quantity is dimensional or nondimensional. Remember that nondimensional aerodynamic coefficients are designed to be scale-independent under similarity.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to an incorrect scaling law and wrong option (B) in this question.

common_mistakes.mistake: Thinking that the larger airfoil has smaller Cp,min because the same flow is 'spread over a larger area' (choosing 0.5).
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Intuitive but incorrect reasoning that area directly reduces coefficients instead of forces.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Separate in your mind: forces scale with area, but coefficients are normalized by area and dynamic pressure, so they remain the same under similarity.
common_mistakes.consequence: Incorrect answer and misunderstanding of how coefficients are defined.

common_mistakes.mistake: Ignoring the phrase 'same family' and 'same angle of attack' and overthinking about different shapes or stall behavior.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Underline key conditions in the question (same family, same \alpha, same flow) and recall similarity principles before doing any math.
common_mistakes.consequence: Wasted time and possible confusion, though may still guess correctly.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: Coefficients are Constant with Copying (same shape, same flow).
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Nondimensional aerodynamic coefficients stay the same when you scale a geometrically similar body in a dynamically similar flow.
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use when thinking about model vs full-scale tests and scaling laws.

flashcards.front: What is the definition of pressure coefficient \(C_p\) in external aerodynamics?
flashcards.back: Pressure coefficient: \(C_p = \dfrac{p - p_\infty}{\tfrac{1}{2} \\rho_\infty V_\infty^2}\), a nondimensional measure of local pressure relative to freestream dynamic pressure.

flashcards.front: For two geometrically similar airfoils at same Mach, Reynolds, and angle of attack, how do their \(C_p(x/c)\) distributions compare?
flashcards.back: They are identical in nondimensional form: \(C_p\) as a function of \(x/c\) is the same for both, so \(C_{p,\min}\) is also the same.

flashcards.front: A wing model is built at half scale and tested at same Mach and Reynolds as full scale. How does \(C_l\) of the model compare to full scale?
flashcards.back: The lift coefficient \(C_l\) is the same for model and full-scale wing under geometric and dynamic similarity.

flashcards.front: Does doubling the chord length of an airfoil (same family, same flow) change \(C_{p,\min}\)? Why or why not?
flashcards.back: No. \(C_{p,\min}\) is nondimensional and depends on shape, Mach, Reynolds, and angle of attack, not on absolute size, under similarity.

real_world_context.application: Wind-tunnel testing of scale models to predict full-scale aircraft performance.
real_world_context.industry_example: A 1:5 scale model of a transport aircraft wing is tested at matching Mach and Reynolds numbers. The measured \(C_p\) distribution and \(C_l\) are used directly for full-scale design because coefficients are scale-independent under similarity.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: If engineers incorrectly assumed coefficients change with size, they would mispredict lift, drag, and stall margins, leading to unsafe or inefficient designs.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Recognize it as a pure similarity/nondimensional question. Recall that coefficients like \(C_p\) do not change with scale under geometric and dynamic similarity; answer 1.0 quickly.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If a question mentions 'same family', 'same angle of attack', and nondimensional coefficients, 1.0 is often a strong candidate unless other parameters (Mach, Re) differ.
exam_strategy.time_management: Aim to solve within 1â€“2 minutes; do not overcomplicate with detailed calculations.

search_keywords: model to full scale correlation aerodynamics

alternative_methods.name: Dimensional analysis using Buckingham Pi theorem
alternative_methods.description: Start from variables affecting pressure on an airfoil (p, p_\infty, \rho_\infty, V_\infty, c, \mu, etc.) and use Buckingham Pi theorem to derive nondimensional groups like Cp, Mach, and Reynolds. Show that Cp is a function of nondimensional parameters only, not of absolute size.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Gives a rigorous foundation for why Cp is scale-independent. Cons: More time-consuming and mathematically involved than needed for this simple GATE question.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Useful for deeper understanding of similarity and when studying more complex scaling problems.

connections_to_other_subjects.Fluid Mechanics: Similarity and nondimensional parameters (Reynolds, Froude, Mach numbers) are central in fluid mechanics and are used in hydraulic models and ship design.
connections_to_other_subjects.Flight Mechanics: Lift and drag coefficients from aerodynamics are used directly in performance and stability calculations, assuming scale-independent coefficients.
connections_to_other_subjects.Experimental Methods: Wind-tunnel testing and data reduction rely on nondimensional coefficients to extrapolate from model to full scale.

deeper_dive_topics: Dynamic similarity and limitations when matching both Mach and Reynolds numbers in wind tunnels
Compressibility corrections and similarity rules (Prandtl-Glauert, Gothert, Karman) for airfoils
Transonic similarity rules and their use in collapsing drag data for different thickness ratios

syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Incompressible and compressible flow over airfoils and wings; aerodynamic coefficients and similarity parameters
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: Well-aligned with the need to test understanding of nondimensional coefficients and similarity, which are fundamental for using wind-tunnel data and scaling results.

rag_quality.notes: RAG provided related aerodynamics content (airfoils, similarity rules, transonic similarity) but did not explicitly define pressure coefficient or directly state scale independence. Core reasoning relied on general aerodynamics knowledge, with RAG supporting the broader concept of similarity and use of nondimensional coefficients.

future_questions_potential: Ask how lift and drag forces (not coefficients) scale when airfoil size is doubled, given same Cp distribution and freestream conditions.
Include Mach and Reynolds number changes and ask how Cp,min and Cl change when only geometric similarity is maintained.
Provide a Cp(x/c) plot for a model airfoil and ask students to compute lift coefficient and then scale to a full-size wing.
Ask about limitations of similarity when exact Reynolds number matching is not possible in wind-tunnel testing.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: Two airfoils of the same family are operating at the same angle of attack. The dimensions of one airfoil are twice as large as the other one. The ratio of the minimum pressure coefficient of the larger airfoil to the minimum pressure coefficient of the smaller airfoil is
